contextId.information: This metaphor means the number of people supporting David increased. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: grew stronger and stronger

contextId.information: Abner's increasing power over Saul's family is spoken of as if he became physically stronger. AT: "Abner gained more power over the family and supporters of Saul" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Abner made himself strong in the house of Saul

contextId.information: Abner speaks of himself as the head of a dog, which the Israelites considered to be loyal to anyone who fed them. Here "belongs to Judah" implies that Abner's loyalty is to Judah, to which David belonged, and not to Saul's house. AT: "Am I a traitor for Judah?" or "I am not a traitor working for David!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Am I a dog's head that belongs to Judah?

contextId.information: Yahweh destroying David's enemies is spoken of as if Yahweh cut them off, as one would cut a piece of cloth or cut a branch from a tree. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have cut off all your enemies

contextId.information: The phrase "become a stench" is a metaphor for "they had become offensive." AT: "they had become offensive like a bad smell to David" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they had become a stench to David

contextId.information: Here the author speaks of her lamenting very much as if it were deep inside her. AT: "she lamented very much" or "she lamented greatly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: she lamented deeply

contextId.information: Here the author describes how David was very angry as if his body were physically hot because of his anger. AT: "David became furious with" or "David became very angry with" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: David was hot with anger against

contextId.information: Here Yahweh describes David having his master's wives as his own wives, by saying that they are "in his arms." AT: "your master's wives as your own" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: your master's wives into your arms

contextId.information: Here Yahweh speaks of how he gave David his authority as king over Israel and Judah as if he gave him the houses of Israel and Judah as a gift. The phrase "the house of" means "the people of." AT: "I also gave you authority as king over the people of Israel and Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I also gave you the house of Israel and Judah

contextId.information: "in full daylight." The idea of doing something "openly" or in a way that people are fully aware of what is happening is often spoken about as being done in the "daylight." AT: "openly" or "and everyone will see what is happening" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in broad daylight

contextId.information: "Taking" a place or landmark means to take control of it. AT: "have taken control of the city's water supply" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: have taken the city's water supply

contextId.information: "Taking" a place or landmark means to take control of it. AT: "take control of it ... take control of the city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: take it ... take the city

contextId.information: Here the author speaks of Absalom urging David to let Amnon come as if he were putting physical pressure on him. AT: "Absalom begged David for Amnon to come" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Absalom pressed David

contextId.information: Here the sons crying out is spoken of as if their voices were something they lifted into the sky. AT: "cried out" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: raised their voices

contextId.information: This speaks of the land which Yahweh gave to the Israelites as if it were an inheritance that a father leaves his children. AT: "out of the land that God gave us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: out of the inheritance of God

contextId.information: Here the woman describes the difficulty of speaking to the king and keeping him from finding out the truth by comparing it to a person not being about to escape in any direction. AT: "no one can keep you from knowing the truth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: no one can escape to the right hand ... the king has spoken

contextId.information: This sentence means Absalom convinced the men to be loyal to him rather than to David. Here the author speaks of how the people became loyal to Absalom by saying that he stole their hearts. AT: "In this way, Absalom convinced the men of Israel to be loyal to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: So Absalom stole the hearts of the men of Israel

contextId.information: Having a descendant of Saul being allowed to rule is spoken of as the kingdom being restored to their family. AT: "will allow me to rule the kingdom that my grandfather ruled" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will restore my father's kingdom to me

contextId.information: Ziba is not literally bowing before the king when he is speaking here. This means that he will serve the king with the same amount of humility he would be showing if he were literally bowing before him. AT: "I will humbly serve you" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I bow in humility to you

contextId.information: Here the king and his people being killed is describes as if they were "swallowed" by their enemy. AT: "the king will be killed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the king will be swallowed up

contextId.information: Here the man speaks about how the king knows about almost everything that happens as if everything were a physical object he knew the location of. AT: "there is nothing that the king does not know" or "the king hears about everything that happens" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: there is nothing hidden from the king

contextId.information: Here Ahimaaz speaks of running to go and tell the king the good news as if the good news were a object that he were carrying. AT: "run to tell the king the good news" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: run to the king with the good news

contextId.information: Here the watchman looking to see something is spoken of as if he lifted up his eyes. AT: "and looked out beyond the city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and raised his eyes

contextId.information: Here Ahimaaz speaks of the men opposing the king as if they were were raising their hands before him. AT: "the men who opposed and fought against my master the king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the men who lifted up their hand against my master the king

contextId.information: Here restoring the king's authority to rule is spoken of as bringing him back to his palace. AT: "to restore the king's authority as king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to bring the king back to his palace

contextId.information: Here the king describes how they are related by saying that they have the same flesh and bones. Also the implied words "you are" may be added to the second phrase. AT: "You are my brothers, my relatives" or "You are my brothers, you are my flesh and bone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
contextId.quote: You are my brothers, my flesh and bone

contextId.information: Here David speaks of them being related by saying that they have the same flesh and bones. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:19:11|19:12]]. AT: "my relative" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my flesh and my bone

contextId.information: This speaks of the men being united in their loyalty to the king as if they were one man with the same mind. AT: "and they were united together" or "they were united in their loyalty to the king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: as one man

contextId.information: Mephibosheth speaks of how his relatives had deserved to be executed as if they had already been executed and were dead. AT: "all my father's house deserved for my master the king to order them to be executed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: all my father's house were dead men before my master the king

contextId.information: This speaks of the importance of this city among the nation of Israel as if it were a well respected mother. AT: "city that everyone in Israel respects like they would their mother" or "city that is very important and that Israel respects" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: city that is a mother in Israel

contextId.information: Here the woman speaks of the army destroying the city as if the city were food to be swallowed. AT: "destroy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: swallow up

contextId.information: The "lamp of Israel" is a metaphor that refers to David's leadership and the idea that if David were to die, the people of Israel would have no clear direction. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you do not put out the lamp of Israel

contextId.information: This is Yahweh's response to David's cry for help from his enemies. David uses the imagery of the earth shaking and fire coming from Yahweh to emphasize Yahweh's terrible anger. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Then the earth shook ... were ignited by it

contextId.information: Here Yahweh's anger is compared to fire, which causes coals to ignite and burn. AT: "The flame from his mouth set coals on fire" or "He also sent burning coals from his mouth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Coals were ignited by it

contextId.information: David continues describing Yahweh, whom he compares to a storm, coming to save him from his enemies. This emphasizes God's power and anger towards David's enemies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: From the lightning before him ... lightning bolts and dispersed them

contextId.information: When Yahweh shouted in his attack against David's enemies, it is compared to his power to create upheaval in the deepest parts of the ocean and the earth. This shows his great power and fierce anger. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Then the water channels appeared ... breath of his nostrils

contextId.information: David compares Yahweh's power to save him to a shield that protects a soldier from his enemy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the shield of your salvation

contextId.information: Here David compares himself to a wild animal. AT: "I completely destroyed them like a wild animal devouring its prey" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I devoured them and smashed them

contextId.information: The word "ignite" means start a fire. Here Yahweh's anger is compared to that of a fire. AT: "the anger of Yahweh started to burn like a fire" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the anger of Yahweh was ignited against Israel
